greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = sum of the exponents occurring only once each in the prime-factorization of n.
link: Diana Mecum and Michael De Vlieger, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000 (first 1000 terms from Diana Mecum)
example: 4200 = 2^3 * 3^1 * 5^2 * 7^1. The exponents of the prime factorization are therefore 3,1,2,1. The exponents occurring exactly once are 2 and 3. So a(4200) = 2+3 = 5.
mathematica: Table[Total@ Flatten@ Select[Split[Sort[FactorInteger[n][[All, -1]]]], Length@ # == 1 &] - Boole[n == 1], {n, 105}] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Sep 21 2017 *)
program: (PARI) a(n) = my(f=factor(n)[,2]); sum(k=1, #f, f[k]*(#select(x->(x==f[k]), f) == 1)); \\ _Michel Marcus_, Sep 22 2017
results.author: _Leroy Quet_, Jan 07 2008
ext: More terms from _Diana L. Mecum_, Jul 17 2008
